drawing_instructions.thinking: The canvas is empty and I'm feeling melancholic. I want to start by drawing a wilting flower - a universal symbol of sadness and decay. I'll begin with the drooping stem using the wiggle brush to create an unsteady, weak-looking line in a dark green shade. The wavering line will emphasize the fragility and sadness of the moment.

I see the wilting stem has been drawn, expressing fragility. To enhance the feeling of sadness, I'll add a drooping, withered petal falling from where the flower would be. I'll use the marker brush with a muted, melancholic light red color, making the petal look like a tear drop falling from above. The curved shape will emphasize the downward movement, symbolizing depression and loss.

Looking at the wilting stem and fallen petal, I want to emphasize the feeling of loneliness and sadness by adding a soft, melancholic halo around the drooping petal - like a fading memory or distant hope. I'll use the spray brush to create a diffuse, ethereal circle of scattered dots around the petal area, making it look like it's dissolving into nothingness. This will add to the emotional weight of the piece.

Looking at the wilting flower with its drooping petal and misty halo, I want to add another wilting flower stem beside it to emphasize loneliness and companionship lost. I'll draw another wiggling stem, but even more bent and broken, leaning away from the first one - like two friends separated. This second stem will be drawn slightly to the right, using the same dark Keppel color but with more pronounced waves to show deeper distress.

Looking at the two wilting stems, fallen petal, and misty halo, I want to enhance the melancholic atmosphere by adding gentle rain-like teardrops using the spray brush. I'll create a scattered pattern of dots above the wilting flowers, denser at the top and fading as they fall, symbolizing tears and the weight of sadness. This will complete the emotional narrative of the piece, creating a somber atmosphere that reflects deep sorrow.

Looking at the two wilting stems and the sorrowful atmosphere created by the spray effects, I want to add a gentle, wilting heart shape near the top - a broken heart dissolving into tears. I'll use the spray brush to create a diffuse, fading heart that appears to be disintegrating, positioned above the stems around coordinates (425-475, 200-250). This will symbolize emotional pain and heartbreak, with the scattered dots giving it a fragile, ephemeral quality that matches our melancholic mood.

Looking at the composition with its wilting stems, fading heart, and gentle rain of tears, I want to add a heavy dark cloud mass at the top using spray brush. This dark cloud will represent the overwhelming weight of sadness, positioned above everything else around (425-475, 175-225). The cloud will be dense and heavy in the center, spreading out more diffusely at the edges, like a dark thought that consumes everything. This will complete the metaphor of emotional darkness hanging over our delicate, wilting scene.

Looking at the melancholic scene with its dark cloud, wilting stems, and scattered tears, I want to add another spiral tendril falling limply from the dark cloud, emphasizing the feeling of being weighed down by sadness. I'll use the wiggle brush in the dark Keppel color to create a curling, drooping line that seems to be pulled down by gravity, positioned to the right of the existing elements. This will add to the sense of defeat and despair in the composition.

Looking at the sorrowful scene with its dark cloud, wilting stems, and spiral tendrils, I want to add one final drooping tendril to complete the composition. Like tears or strands of weeping willow, these curved lines express deep melancholy. I'll place this new wiggling tendril slightly to the right of the others, making it curve and droop even more dramatically to emphasize the weight of sadness. The placement will create a balanced but heavy feeling, like nothing can escape the pull of gravity and despair.

Looking at the melancholic scene with its dark cloud, wilting stems, and drooping tendrils, I want to add one more weeping tendril that emphasizes the deep sadness. I'll position it slightly to the right of the existing ones, using the wiggle brush to create a wavering, uncertain line that seems to be pulled down by the weight of sorrow. This additional tendril will complete the sense of a weeping willow effect, with the curves expressing emotional fragility and despair.

Looking at the deeply melancholic scene with its dark cloud and weeping tendrils, I want to add one final drooping tendril that's slightly shorter than the others, like a broken whisper trailing off. This last one will be placed to the right of the others, creating a natural fade-out effect that mirrors how hope sometimes quietly slips away. The wiggle brush will create that same uncertain, wavering line that perfectly captures the fragility of the moment.

Looking at the melancholic scene with its dark cloud and weeping tendrils, I want to add a few more delicate teardrops falling between the tendrils. The spray brush will create soft, scattered dots that look like tears suspended in mid-fall, adding to the feeling of quiet sorrow. I'll place these between the existing tendrils around coordinates (480-540, 250-350), making them more concentrated at the top and more sparse as they fall, like tears that fade before reaching the ground.

Looking at the sorrowful scene with its dark cloud, falling tears, and weeping tendrils, I want to add more delicate teardrops using the spray brush, but this time focusing on the leftmost area that feels a bit empty. I'll create a gentle cascade of dots that appears to be falling from the dark cloud's edge, around coordinates (380-420, 230-350). This will balance the composition while emphasizing the theme of endless tears and deepening sadness. The spray pattern will be lighter and more dispersed, like the last quiet tears when you're too exhausted to cry anymore.

Looking at the deeply emotional scene, I want to add some final teardrops that seem to dissolve into nothingness, symbolizing how sadness can feel endless. I'll use the spray brush to create a very light, dispersed pattern of dots in the lower right area (550-650, 400-480), making them increasingly sparse as they fall. This will complete the composition by suggesting that even as the tears fade away, the sadness lingers, trailing off into empty space.

Looking at the sorrowful composition with its dark cloud, weeping tendrils, and scattered tears, I want to add one more drooping, spiral tendril that curves even more dramatically than the others. I'll place it at the far right of the existing tendrils, making it twist and curl more tightly upon itself like a spirit crushed by sadness. This final tendril will use the wiggle brush in the darkest Keppel shade to symbolize the deepest despair, creating a shape that seems to fold in on itself like someone curling up when overwhelmed by grief.
